Name: RiaCon Window Pattern Card (fan expansion for Sagrada)
Description:
This window pattern card is a fan made expansion for the Sagrada boardgame, featuring level 5 and 6 patterns.
We are listening to you asking why this card has the name "RiaCon"... Allright, allright, you win. We will tell you the story!

In Portugal - similar to other countries - we have annual conventions to play boardgames with people from everywhere.
We belong to the boardgamers group of Aveiro, a city that is known as Portugal's Venice :)
This city is well known for it's river named "Ria de Aveiro", an arm from the sea that passes through the city.
That's the reason why this convention is named RiaCon and the card received the name by inheritance.

As volunteers in RiaCon we had the crazy ideia of designing one card to Sagrada to mark the difference in this event.
In this way, we could encourage the participants that didn't knew Sagrada to try it out and the ones that already knew the game to play it once again.

Now we are sharing it with you and we hope that you enjoy playing with this expansion as much as we do!
Families: Organizations: The Game Artisans of Canada

Name: Deduction Name Game
Description:
Deduction Name Game is a party game aimed at guessing the secret names of other players. To start, each player will write down a secret name. Players should try to write a name not easily connected with themselves, as the goal is to use deduction skills to figure out the names each player has secretly written.

All written names will be placed into a bowl, and read out loud once.

The starting player tries to guess the name of another player. If they are right, they get that player as their teammate! If they are wrong, that player becomes the guesser, and the game continues. As the teams grow, more names are guessed, until there is only one secret name left – the winner!

-description from designer

Name: Bargain Quest: Chaotic Goods
Description: Bargain Quest: Chaotic Goods introduces thirteen new heroes and nine new employees to Bargain Quest, with you replacing all the duplicate heroes from the base game when you use this expansion.

Name: Dinamic-Goal Binaca
Description:
3 custom dice for this simple and old Push-Your-Luck soccer game.

Red and blue dice are for the 2 teams, white dice is for shooting on goal.

The language of this game is italian, roll the wooden dice and try to win the football match.

Name: Sunny and Stormy Day!
Description:
Sunny and Stormy Day is a cooperative game that encourages discussion of feelings through the metaphor of "sunny" and "stormy" experiences. The game has 3 separate activities, a variant on the classic tile matching game, and a draw bag with tokens that ask for the players to discuss a part of their day, and a book that tells the story illustrated on the tiles.

The book tells the story of a day in the life Max the Hedgehog. During the day he experiences "sunny" and "stormy" events. The draw bag contains 3 tokens, a sun, a cloud, and a rainbow. They ask the participants to share part of their day that was sunny, stormy, or to share something they are looking forward to. The book and the tokens support the game in teaching about emotions but are not a part of the game.

Twenty sunny and stormy scenes from the book are paired together to create 10 matching sets (for example having fun splashing in puddles and being cold and scared in the rain). The goal of the game is to find all the pairs. The rules state three variants of increasing challenge. Variant 1 is a cooperative matching game in which tiles are placed face up. Variant 2 is a cooperative matching game in which tiles are placed face down. In variant 3, Max's day is almost over and he is remembering the sunny and stormy parts of the day. He must find all pairs before it is night and time for bed. This variant adds 4 nighttime tiles to the cooperative matching game that when revealed require the players to add a puzzle piece to a night puzzle. To win the players must find all matches before the puzzle is completed (6 puzzle pieces). Night tiles are not removed from the board when revealed. There are 4 tiles and 6 puzzle pieces so if players remember where the tiles are they will win.
Families: Series: Pre-School Skills Builder Games (Peaceable Kingdom)

Name: Martial Art: Battlefields
Description:
The battle continues for feudal Japan in this expansion to Martial Art. Battlefields introduces two new mechanics: terrain and weather.

Terrain cards may be played before battle to augment your battle card and affect the outcome. Because terrain is played before battle but the effects don't happen until later, other players may guess your intention and act accordingly. Alternatively, terrain may be used as a feint to trick your opponents before you surprise them with an unexpected battle card.

Weather cards are shuffled into the land deck at the start of the game. When a weather card is drawn, its effect continues until a new weather is drawn to replace it. Weather will affect the battles in unpredictable ways, forcing you to adapt your strategy to what the battlefield is giving you. Will you charge your troops through the snow to capture a valuable bridge? Will you send your troops to battle during a severe drought? It is up to you to decide if the risk is worth the reward.

Name: Sailor's War in the Pacific
Description: Sailor's War in the Pacific is a strategic level wargame of the Pacific War from the viewpoint of the shipping industry. Japanese player classifies transport ships into three divisions and uses them: A) ships for army's logistics, B) ships for navy's logistics and C) ships for transportation of natural resources from Southeast Asia to the mainland of Japan. Allied player aims to destroy these ships. If there is no resource in the mainland of Japan at the end of final turn, Allied player wins. Otherwise, Japanese player wins.

Name: Dogeza in the Pacific
Description: Dogeza in the Pacific is a strategic level wargame of the Pacific War. In a two-player case, the flavor of this game is a compact edition of Avalon Hill's Victory in the Pacific, but in a four-player case, each player (Japanese Army, Japanese Navy, U.S. Army and U.S. Navy) fights each other in order to save face of each organization. Sometimes army player cannot help using navy units. Sometimes navy player cannot help using army units. If so, they cannot help performing dogeza (prostration, kowtow) to borrow the unit even though it is losing face. Therefore, they fight each other for their organization's face rather than their motherland's future.

Name: Masasuke
Description: Masasuke is a card game of color-coordinate battle among female servants of the nobility in the Heian period, Japanese medieval times. The playing cards are divided into two decks: coordinate cards and color cards. At first, each player draws six color cards and one coordinate card, and then, in order to make nice color coordination of dresses, they continue drawing and discarding by following the instructions of the coordinate card.

Name: University of Tokyo Protests 1968–1969
Description: University of Tokyo Protests 1968–1969 is a four-player game of the University of Tokyo protests from June 1968 to January 1969 by using GMT Games' COIN system. Each player plays the role of insurgency ("All-Campus Joint Struggle League" or "Democratic Youth League of Japan and Certain Party") or counterinsurgency ("Police" or "University and Ministry of Education, Science and Culture"), and then the players fight each other in order to achieve each different victory condition.

Name: Legio VI Macedonica
Description:
Legio VI Macedonica is a set of miniatures wargames rules aimed to allow large battles of Roman Middle Republican  period (400-100 BC) to be resolved relatively quickly. It's meant for 6mm figures but could easily be adapted to larger (or smaller!) figures.

The rules are derived from the same designer's Comitatus set of Dark Ages rules, but slimmed down to allow larger battles to be fought in less time. Troops are classed a relatively small number of troop types with minimal differentiation based on equipment; the focus is on troop quality and, especially, generals' limited means of controlling their forces.

The rules are freely available from the designer's webpage, along with sister sets covering adjoining periods:

Legio VI Julia Augusta, for 100 BC to AD 250
Legio VI Constantiniani, for AD 250 to AD 600
Legio VI Diadochi, for Alexander and the Successors

Name: Legio VI Constantiniani
Description:
Legio VI Constantiniani is a set of miniatures wargames rules aimed to allow large battles of Roman Late Imperial period (AD 250-600) to be resolved relatively quickly. It's meant for 6mm figures but could easily be adapted to larger (or smaller!) figures.

The rules are derived from the same designer's Comitatus set of Dark Ages rules, but slimmed down to allow larger battles to be fought in less time. Troops are classed a relatively small number of troop types with minimal differentiation based on equipment; the focus is on troop quality and, especially, generals' limited means of controlling their forces.

The rules are freely available from the designer's webpage, along with sister sets covering adjoining periods:

Legio VI Julia Augusta, for 100 BC to AD 250
Legio VI Macedonica, for 400-100 BC
Legio VI Diadochi, for Alexander and the Successors

Name: Legio VI Diadochi
Description:
Legio VI Diadochi is a set of miniatures wargames rules aimed to allow large battles of Alexander the Great and the Successors to be resolved relatively quickly. It's meant for 6mm figures but could easily be adapted to larger (or smaller!) figures.

The rules are derived from the same designer's Comitatus set of Dark Ages rules, but slimmed down to allow larger battles to be fought in less time. Troops are classed a relatively small number of troop types with minimal differentiation based on equipment; the focus is on troop quality and, especially, generals' limited means of controlling their forces.

The rules are freely available from the designer's webpage, along with sister sets focusing on the Romans:

Legio VI Julia Augusta, for 100 BC to AD 250
Legio VI Macedonica, for 400-100 BC
Legio VI Constantiniani, for AD 250-600

Name: Bla Bla Cat
Description:
Once a decade, a big tournament is organized. Contestants from all over the world compete to win the ultimate prize: the goldenfish!
This trophy grants to his owner an abondance of fishes for the rest of his life. But to be the chosen one, you must defeat your opponents, avoid the tricks and persuade the jury.

Bla Bla Cat is a party game where you have to defeat your opponents in a amazing debate tournament.

When a player is eliminated, he still plays as member of the jury until the end of the game.

—description from the publisher

Name: Indie Dev
Description:
In IndieDev, players are independent video game developers trying to earn prestige in the game industry by creating and releasing critically acclaimed game projects.  Players will juggle the many aspects of running an independent video game company, including completing side jobs to gain extra income; taking courses to  improve abilities; figuring out how to afford marketing;  investing in marketing in order to increase market visibility. Did the game bomb on release?  Players should make the most of the situation, never giving up.  Did the game earn critical success and sell? Players must take that hard-earned cash and use it productively; otherwise players will end up struggling once again.
Players that work through the multiple challenges effectively will triumph within one of the most challenging but rewarding industries.  The player that earned the most prestige will win this game and of course win at life (Mostly win, they still will devote most of their waking life to their next project).

—description from the designer

Name: Crossing Fate: The Battle of Issus, November 333 BC
Description:
Crossing Fate is an introductory level wargame of the Battle of Issus that was fought by the forces of Darius the Great, King of Persia and Alexander the Great of Macedon along with his Greek Allies. To insure the security of the Macedonian Hegemony, and to wrest control of the Persian Empire’s territories bordering on the Aegean and Mediterranean, Alexander launched an invasion of Anatolia. The first major battle was fought against the Persian satraps of Anatolia at the Granicus river. Alexander’s forces garnered a decisive victory, and in response Darius traveled west to personally organize his troops for a showdown with the Macedonian interloper. The two sides met along the Pinarus river that flows into the Gulf of Issus. The fates of two empires were about to collide.

—description from the publisher
Families: History: Wars of Alexander the Great

Name: Viva la Muerte! The Battle of Brunete, July 1937
Description:
“Viva la Muerte!”—Rallying cry of the Nationalist forces during much of the Spanish Civil War.

“The boys were confident and kidding. But there was a solemn, deep undertone to all the kidding for we realized fully that many would not come out of it alive.—Reflection by Samuel Levinger, member of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, about the eve of the Republican Brunete offensive.

The first half of 1937 was an almost complete series of disasters for the Republican cause in the north and west of Spain. Only in the territories leading to Madrid and to the south were the Nationalists thwarted, but at an increasingly bloody cost. The Soviet Union sent massive amounts of weaponry and equipment, while volunteers poured in from throughout Europe, the US and Canada to support the Republican cause. The leadership of the Republican military decided to launch a counter-attack against the Nationalists that were deployed directly west of Madrid. The plan was to attack from the Republican held northern salient to take the crucial town of Brunete, and the main highway leading to Madrid to its south. Success here would compel the fascists to withdraw from the territory closest to the national capitol, and give the Republicans a badly needed victory. One of the largest battles of the war to-date was about to unfold.

Can you do as well or better than your historical counterparts? Learn and enjoy!

—description from the publisher

Name: Brave and Noble Fights Expansion II: The Formosa Campaigns, 1884-1895
Description:
The Battle for Formosa was the final large-scale campaign associated with the Sino-Japanese War of 1894-95.  The island was ceded to Japan in April 1895 by the Treaty of Shimonoseki which ended the war but the island proclaimed its independence from China and formed a republic in May 1895 following Japan's victory.  The Japanese, therefore, mobilized their forces to gain control of their new territory.  Although ill-prepared for the Japanese onslaught, and the Chinese Empire unable or unwilling to offer any support, the island's garrison and inhabitants put up a bitter and protracted resistance, one that cost both sides dearly.

In 1884 and 1885, France invaded Formosa in an attempt to wrest control of the island from the Chinese following their campaign in Indochina and the attack at Foochow that resulted in the destruction of the Fukien Fleet. Already over-stretched and with most of their warships badly in need of refit and repair, Admiral Courbet still went ahead with the invasion. The French landed at Keelung, but then became bogged down in trench warfare. The Chinese were able to send reinforcements and supplies to the Formosan garrison through the rather weak French blockade. Although stalemated on Formosa, the French were able to capture the Pescadore islands when they took control of the key island of Peng-hu. In January and February, both sides sent reinforcements, escalating the conflict that threatened possible intervention by other governments to end the French aggression. This scenario covers the last months of the conflict when it could have gone either way.

Can you do as well or better than your historical counterparts?

—description from the publisher
Families: Series: Brave and Noble Fights (High Flying Dice)

Name: Panzer Grenadier: Soviet Paratroopers
Description:
May Day Golden Journal:
Soviet Paratroopers

Our May Day 2017 Golden Journal features our first variant for Panzer Grenadier (Modern), as Soviet paratroopers land in the Negev Desert to march on the Israeli nuclear facility at Dimona. This was an option discussed by the Soviet leadership but never actually executed, and for the 50th Anniversary of the Six-Day War we have the pieces to let you try it out in 1967: Sword of Israel.

The Journal includes a set of 24 full-color, laser-cut pieces depicting a Soviet parachute battalion from the elite 103rd Guards Airborne Division.

Name: Fruit Flip!
Description:
Fruit Flip is a bright color matching, hex-card flipping game of memory, strategy, and sabotage. On their turn, each player places a card from their hand following placement rules.  After playing your card, flip all  adjacent cards. Keep as many of your chosen fruit face up by the end of the game, while flipping your opponent's fruit down. At the end of the game the player with the highest number of their fruit WINS the game!

Plays in 2 Modes!

Basic Fruit Flip!
Enjoy this slower, relaxed version of the game encouraging more strategy and sabotage. This version can be enjoyed with 2-6 players. Great for in between long difficult games, bar game, used in classrooms! Appropriate ages start at 6 but great for all ages and type of gamer.

Multiplayer Death Match
Pick up the pace with this exciting card-dropping version of Fruit Flip! 2 teams, 2 decks, facing off against each other to place their cards first. Only the team that plays all of their cards first will get to determine the winner of the game!

—description from the publisher

Name: Fantastory
Description:
Every card is a doorway into a world: the Fantastory world. Invent exciting and fun new stories each time and then try and remember them.

Shuffle the story cards, take the first 10 and place them face up on the table. The narrator tells a brief story taking inspiration from 5 or 6 of the 10 cards. When he tells a part of the story which refer to a card, the players should identify and indicate it.

Once the story has ended, the narrator shuffles the 10 cards and place them faceup on the table. The game ends as the correct sequence of the story is reconstructed by the players.

Name: Holiday Photos
Description:
The animals on holiday have lost their favorite possessions: can you find them all by looking at their photos?

Each player chooses an animal tile and places face up in front of them. Then all animal and object tiles are placed face down on the table.

All the players play simultaneously. Each player turns over an object tile searching for one which shows an object his animal is wearing. If correct, the player joins the object tile he found with the animal tile who is wearing the object. If incorrect, the player turns the object tile back face down. In either case, the player goes on searching for other tiles to be joined.

If a player joins a tile, he can now search for both the tile showing the second object the animal is wearing and an animal who is wearing the object which he has just found.

The first player to join 8 tiles wins.

Name: Mission Critical: Mars
Description:
From the Box:
Work together as a team of astronauts on a thrilling journey to Mars! Face dangerous emergencies and solve problems together as the electronic Command Computer narrates your adventure.  It will take teamwork, strategy and a little luck to guide your spacecraft to a successful landing on the Red Planet!

From the Instructions:
Your team of brave astronauts has accepted a perilous mission to Mars.  It is vital that the astronauts stay healthy and perform Mission Tasks throughout the journey in preparation for the difficult Mars Landing.

Space is full of hazards, and emergencies are common.  When the Command Computer sounds the alarm, the clock starts ticking.  The team must quickly assess the situation and execute the correct Emergency Procedure.  The team wins only if the ship survives the journey, and the crew successfully executes the Mars Landing Procedure.

The game can end one of three ways.

Spacecraft is Destroyed
If the players fail four Emergency Procedures, the spacecraft takes more damage than it can sustain and is destroyed.  The players lose the game.

Landing Procedure Fails
If the players are not able to successfully complete the Mars Landing Procedure before time runs out, the landing vehicle crashing on to the surface of Mars.  The players lose the game.

Landing Procedure Succeeds
If the players successfully complete the Mars Landing Procedure, then its time to celebrate a successful mission.  The players win the game!

Name: Macacos me mordam!
Description:
In "Macacos me mordam! (Monkeys bite me!)" the players will need agility and a firm hand to help their little monkey to hang in the treetops, collect bananas and increase the height of the tree!

In the game each player is a little monkey trying to climb a tree to collect as many bananas as possible. The tree, consisting of trunk cards and treetop cards, is being set up as the bananas become scarce.

The game starts with a one-floor tree with some bananas on top of it. One at a time, the players must choose between hanging their monkey on the tree and recover a banana or add another floor to the tree. Either way, he must be careful not to knock down the tree, or he will not earn his banana.

Whoever gets 8 bananas first wins the match! The game stimulates fine motor coordination and attention, as well as basics of quantification.

Name: The Lost Provinces
Description:
The shocking defeat of France in 1940 created a unique opportunity for Thailand to regain territory it had lost decades before. When Vichy France refused to give it back, fascist leader Plaek Phibunsongkhram launched a blitzkrieg attack in January 1941. The fighting stopped eighteen days later, and with Japanese mediation, Thailand won back her lost provinces.

This obscure conflict is the subject of designer John Gorkowski’s The Lost Provinces. This is a simple, small, and soloable game that can be played in an evening with new wargamers and grognards alike. It often utilizes traditional mechanisms but with twists and nuances that make them fresh again. For example, combat strengths are compared, to arrive at odds ratios, but those ratios are expressed via a die roll modifier rather than a column on a CRT, which results in greater uncertainty about how a given battle might turn out.

The attacking Thai forces use army, artillery, and air power to bear in along three separate thrust lines. The French forces are more concentrated and have the advantage of defending along interior lines. They’ll have to know when to retreat and when to make the Thai Player fight for every hex.

-description from publisher
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Marvel Dice Masters: X-Force Team Pack
Description: The Marvel Dice Masters: X-Force Team Pack  features the most recognizable members of the X-Force roster, including Cable, Psylocke, Deadpool, and several other heroes making their very first appearance in Dice Masters. Team Packs each include 24 cards and 16 dice, representing eight different characters, and can be combined with any Dice Masters boxed set.

Name: Marvel Dice Masters: Dark X-Men Team Pack
Description: The Marvel Dice Masters: Dark X-Men Team Pack features the most recognizable members of this dark mirror to the X-Men, including Dark Beast, Thunderbird, Mimic, and several other antiheroes making their very first appearance in Dice Masters. Team Packs each include 24 cards and 16 dice, representing eight different characters, and can be combined with any Dice Masters boxed set.

Name: Liar Battleship
Description:
Each player leads a battleship fleet. The object of the game is destroy all of your opponent's ships. In each turn player fire cannon to opponent's fleet, opponent announce hit or miss, but they can lie.But this game is also suitable for those are not good at lying, because all lying ablity is given by ship itself.
player number: 2~4
game timeï¼š15 minutes per player

Each player has 6 ships and 6 empty sea cards,place their 12 cards face down to form a 4x3 formation
Each player on his turn has 2 actions.
For each action, player has 3 options
1) Attack directly: attack 1 of opponent's card. The opponent look at his card. If it is a ship, he say “Hit”, if it is not a ship, he say “Miss”. Put “Hit” or “Miss” token on that card.
2ï¼‰Attack adjacently: attack a space between two cards. The opponent look at both his cards. If either of them is a ship, he say “Hit”; if neither of them is a ship, he say “Miss”. Place “Hit” or “Miss” token  between margin of two cards.
Whenever a ship's life point is equal of below 0 (life points on card minus “Hit” on the ship card and around the ship card), the ship is sunk. Ship's owner shall flip the card face up.
3) Radar scan. Scan one cross point of two margin lines. Opponent look at his cards around scan point.Opponent count all this cards current life point and say that number. Put a radar scan number token on that point.

maybe you think attack adjacently is more powerful,but may ship's ability is against adjacent attack. For example, submarine dodge all adjacent attack and count it as Miss.

Name: Chicago 1920
Description:
Chicago 1920 is an immersive game about the American prohibition era in Chicago where criminal gangs ruled they city and were competing to be the most powerful organization in town.

Chicago 1920 is a medium weight euro-game with high interaction rate among players, low aleatory (luck), and a variable phase turn.     During a turn, players will take up to 6 different criminal actions with unique mechanics (allowing them to earn money, recruit men, do illicit smuggling, bribe politicians and more..) in order to increase their power and score points.

Action sequence changes every turn because is player determined and shared step by step. In deciding what action to play, players will need to find their balance between how many actions and how efficient they are to be played.

Victory paths are multiple, partially hidden and interconnected, you are often pushed to adapt your strategy with the game progress.     Replayability rate and learning curve is remarkable and fun because very much player-dependant and with small aleatory variables.

Game end is not player determined but can be partially predicted by players.
Representing well roaring twenties uncertainty, the game has a special mechanism that gives a small variability in game&#039;s end turn when most powerful criminal organization will be set as winner.

-description from designer

Name: Shootin Iron
Description:
Shootin Iron is a fast-playing miniature game designed for tournament play or pick-up games.  The goal of these rules isn't to simulate realism, but rather to allow you to play out cinematic Wild West shootouts using smart tactics and no small bit of luck.

—description from the introduction

This concise miniatures game shares some cosmetic elements with Shotguns -n- Saddles, (the roleplaying game); however, it is a standalone  miniatures combat game.  The play surface is suggested as 3' x 3', with at least some indication of terrain.  The game assumes figures will be used to denote participating units.  Ranges are given in inches and play assumes the use of a tape measure.  Resolution requires a D6 and a D8.  The game rules primarily deal with fire and movement (as you would expect).  The default starting situation finds two opposing teams ("posse") of six fighters each.

The game is played in rounds; during each round each participant takes a turn.  Turns are executed in specified order and effects take place immediately.  Units utilize a simple facing mechanic and gain benefits depending on type.  Some complicating rules (e.g., "town folk") are optional.  The rules are presented as a single, color PDF document - included are the rules, optional rules, and twelve scenarios (eleven are standard westerns; one is a weird western (zombies).

—user summary

Name: アイドル発掘！Diggers (Find Idol! Diggers)
Description:
This game theme is Japanese pop culture "Idol groups".
This game purpose is taking cards and getting highest score.

Field is created by all cards.
And cards are overlapped randomly.

First, players have some counter chip.
Player pay 1 or 2 or 3 counter chip, and get same numbers of cards.
Be careful, you can get only top most cards.
Finally, most highest score player is the winner.

There are some types of cards.
"Idol", "Manager", "Otaku".

If you have "Manager", you can get additional score.
But if you have same colored "Manager" and "Idol", the Idol loves the Manager and leaves your hand.

If you have "Otaku", you can get additional score, too.
But if you don't have same colored "Idol", the Otaku acts violently, and  decreases your score.

You should control number of your counters, and choose what card you take.

1822+ is a small 18xx expansion to 1822: The Railways of Great Britain. it adds three private companies and six minor companies. This expansion allows more options for late game minor companies to be bought and the permanent L can be bought by a minor company.

Name: Lone Sevens
Description:
Lone Sevens is a solitaire game inspired by and using the components from Stephen Glenn's Rattlebones, published by Rio Grande Games.

Players roll five dice, trying to come up with a set of dice totaling seven, for which victory points are awarded - replacing one of the used die faces.  One unused die face may also be incremented or decremented by one.  If no sevens are rolled, one die face must be replaced by a miss token; one other showing face may still be incremented or decremented.  Once three miss tokens are placed, the game is over; the victory point faces are totaled.

-description from designer

"11:58" is a hand-management/voting card game with social deduction elements. Players take the roles of agents during a conflict between two fictional superpowers.

On each turn a global event card is flipped. Every global event card reveals a crisis which can tick the doomsday clock (represented by eight scoring cards) closer or further from humanity's destruction - these global events also affect the relationship between the two superpowers. Players vote to determine the outcome of each global event card.

With these votes players must balance two (sometimes conflicting) goals - players must both ensure humanity's survival and complete their own unique hidden agenda.

The game ends when the doomsday clock reads entirely red (signalling humanity's destruction) or entirely blue (signalling humanity's salvation). At this point each player reveals their hidden objective; players who have completed all their objectives win the game.

-description from designer

Name: Dragonfire: Dragonborn Wizard Promo Card
Description: Dragonborn Wizard demo/purchase promo from Origins 2017, front and back. Has pureblood printed graphic feature and breath weapon ability.

Name: Trivial Pursuit: X
Description: Trivial Pursuit X was created for adults and features edgy trivia. The game comes with an inked "X" stamp for players to stamp on opponents' foreheads when they answer a question incorrectly. When a player has 5 "X" stamps on their head, they lose.

Name: Heroes of Land, Air & Sea: Pestilence
Description:
Expands Heroes of Land, Air & Sea to support 7 players. Features a floating continent, held above the board with clear plastic stands, and a sunken continent, achieved by laying a transparent blue sheet over an existing island.

Includes 2 new factions: the Birdfolk and the Merfolk, 20 new spell cards, 24 new exploration tokens, and components for a 7th player.

-description from designer
Families: Game: Heroes of Land, Air & Sea

Name: AGGRO: 70's Football Skirmish Rules
Description:
It's a violent time, bands of men bent on destruction march the land under their colours, bringing fear and violence to towns and Cities across the land.

Yes it's the 1970's and gangs from across the country come together using local football allegiances as excuses to have a right royal rumble with each other.

AGGRO provides a set of rules that gives you the opportunity to pit rival gangs against one another in a time when the only things tighter than a professional footballers perms were the shorts he wore on match day.

The rules take a tongue in cheek look at the 70's and have been put together so friends can spend an hour or two taunting one another.

Goal of the game is getting more street cred than the other firm, singing, throwing and bashing against them. Your firm can win by drawing the right playing cards, but your opponent also draws cards to mitigate the effect. Taking turn is eas: alternating, but your opponents action requires a counter actions. Then there are instants changing the gameply, e.g. a traffic warden, who is a source of distraction, as wellas bobby's or a streaker running across the feld.

Just put a firm together and....

—description from the publisher

Name: WAPLEworlds
Description:
ARE YOU AVERAGE ENOUGH TO BE A WAPLE?
You, solo, or with up to three friends take, the role of a member of the worst wrestling family ever, The Waples! Play as Biff the scared wrestler, Spiff the rubber sword-wielding teen, his mom Ivanna and her charms, Randi the out-of-work model, Yodel the chef, or many others.

WAPLEworlds is similar to a dungeon crawler game in that players move their characters, members of the Waple Family, around an 8x8 tile, while encountering Bad Guys and exploring exotic locations such as Pepe's Motor Lodge and the Scam and Save Pawn Shop. Yes, it is comedy themed.

The starter box includes eight playable Waple figures and their Hero Cards, 25 Bad Guy Cards and their standees, over 40 item cards, over 20 Something Happened cards, Mission cards, 12 location tiles a WAPLEworld "newsletter" with rules and pre-made scenarios, 10 dice and money, damage and level tokens.

During a player's turn, he moves his character and can perform an action: search, confront a Bad Guy, use a card, or enter a building. Confronting a Bad Guy can mean to either fight him, bribe him, or run away like a chicken.

Confrontations with Bad Guys: Fighting, Bribing and Running Away, are all controlled by dice rolls based on the stats listed on both the Hero's and the Bad Guys cards.

After that, if not in combat, the player will draw a Something Happened card and execute what it states. If the player enters a location he rolls a die to see if a Mission is currently available there. If it is then he may try to resolve it to save that area by placing the appropriate new tile and Bad Guys onto that tile with the Waple and any that join him.

The third phase of a turn is for any Bad Guy that the player is controlling to either move peacefully or attack the player.

A game can be played with a simple one tile and one mission limit to up to five tiles and over a dozen missions completed, based on the time limit the player wants.  Missions increase in difficulty by placing more Bullies (minions) along with the Big Shot (boss) on the Mission tiles.

On the first tile everyone starts at level 0. After the tile's mission is cleared, all Waples level up and can enhance their skills in the way the player wants, increasing dice rolled for certain stats. Bad Guys level up and roll one more die per level as well. On the second tile the Waples search and complete two missions. The game progresses as such until the final Scenario Mission has been conquered.

-description from designer

Name: Pradün
Description:
The little fiend Pradün came from the Other Side to throw the house into confusion. Help your Family to defeat the diabolic forces that are threatening its quiet life.
But be careful, the enemy hides inside the walls!
There are four card types: Family characters (green), Objectives (white), Demons (red) and Power-ups (blue).
The 72 cards deck features two games in one:
- War at home: for 3-6 players, the complete game
- Run for the Pradün: a basic version using only 46 cards, for 2-4 players
Each player takes the role of a character (one of the family members), possessing a special ability (for example increase power of her/himself or of a fellow family member). However, one of the players is secretly possessed by the Pradün demon: his goal is to score points without being caught while the other players must find out who is it.
On her turn, a player can decide to attack one of the Demons and if she succeeds (having cards that grant a power greater than that of the Demon) she collects the Demon as a Victory Point (VP). During the fight, other players can help or interfere by playing additional cards. Alternatively, the player can draw additional cards to strenghten her hand.
VP can be spent to attack another player, hoping to reveal its objective card: if it is the Pradün, the player wins; if not, the game continues. However, if the Pradün scores 2VP, the player controlling it wins the game.
The game is very funny, with Demons like the "Damned alarm clock" (whose power is equal to the time of the day, in hours) or the "Were-elevator" which tries to crush and block you.
Power-ups can be temporary or permanent and they include things like "Bunny's kiss", the "Garbage sack" or the "No-purpose knife"...
In the simplified version, character's special abilities are neglected and the family members simply race through the house fighting demons to be the first to beat the Pradün; however, other players can also be attacked and slowed down.

Name: Supercards: Perú Campeón
Description:
Supercards is a football card game for 2 players (with an additional solitaire mode). Each player holds five hand cards and tries to form effective combos which enable them to shoot at the opponents goal. The opponent can use block or counterattack cards, but since hands are refilled at the beginning of a turn, one can try to attack when the opponent is low on cards to maximize one's chances. Some special cards simulate fan support and specially gifted players. 
There is a game end card somewhere in the bottom half of the draw pile. When that appears, each player has another two turns before the final whistle sounds. Whoever scored more goals, wins.

In the solitaire mode, the player plays their way through a world cup with group and knock out stages. The opponent is randomized with a simple system.

Name: Perú Cocina
Description: Perú Cocina is a card game about famous Peruvian dishes. Claiming dish cards requires playing all the necessary ingredient cards in the correct order. Each ingredient card shows two different ingredients (in a Dominos style design) of which you can use only one in any given situation, so players have to think carefully which side to use. A player on their turn either places a card or cards near a dish to help preparing it, or places one of their cards into an open pool where anyone can use it. When a player places the last ingredient card for a dish, they claim the card which scores points at the end of the game. The player who finished the most valuable dishes is the winner.

Name: Ozark Air Travel Game
Description:
Made by PrestoMagix, this game was given out on Ozark Airline flights for a limited time. Ozark was bought by TWA in 1986, who in 2001 was acquired by American Airlines.

The game is simple and uses colorform-like stickers of airplanes, servicing equipment and airline personnel on a three-fold nicely drawn landscape board. One to six players place the stickers to crate a collective travel plan on Ozark. In game mechanic terms, this is a very early cooperative game!

Name: Oddassity Party Game
Description:
Oddassity is a social party game of improv style actions. Oddassity is made up of three decks of increasingly absurd dares, plus a fourth deck that plays like Russian roulette. Players take turns flipping Play Cards to determine if an ODDASSITY Card will be performed. The object of the game is to deliver the best performances as determined by the group.

A group of 4 or more players decide the ODDASSITY level your party can handle by picking 1-3 ODDASSITY Decks between NSFP (Not Safe For Prudes), NC (Needs Consent) and R (Racy), or customize their own deck. ODDASSITY CARDS are shuffled, flipped, and read out loud. The player who will obey the ODDASSITY is determined by the Play Cards.

Players take turns flipping Play Cards. There are four types of Play Cards:
YAY!- Player will obey the ODDASSITY Card
NEIGH!- No one obeys the ODDASSITY Card
FLIP!- Discard the current ODDASSITY Card, flip a new one
SAVE AN ASS!- Save yourself or another player from the ODDASSITY

Once the Play deck is exhausted, the group decides which player gave the best performances of the game.

Name: Let Them Eat Shapes
Description:
"Let Them Eat Shapes" is a print and play, and entirely abstract, version of the game Let Them Eat Shrimp. The game board (which is printed on one sheet of paper) has hexagonal spaces, many of which contain shapes that are either hexagons or may be combined to make hexagons. You begin with 4 shapes in your supply and players take turns "placing" them onto the board (i.e., by filling in matching shapes on the board). If you fill in shapes on the board, you gain that shape and mark it as acquired in your supply. When there are no shapes to get from the board, the game ends and players tally their scores. The player with the most points win.

Players familiar with Let Them Eat Shrimp will almost immediately understand the game.

Name: The Tree of Battles: European Warfare AD1300-1500 Wargame Rules
Description:
The Tree of Battles takes Simon Macdowall's Comitatus system and adapts it for Late Medieval Europe, especially the Hundred Years War and the War of the Roses.

The rules emphasize command and control and speed of play rather than details of weapons and equipment, while retaining enough colour to give a feel for the period.
Families: History: Wars of the Guelphs and Ghibellines

Name: Punkapocalyptic
Description:
Punkapocalyptic is a 30 mm miniature game, created by Bad Roll Games, that involves skirmishes between gangs in a pimp and lethal post-apocalyptic world.

The rich and mighty have created mega-cities for themselves and left the rest of the world devastated. The struggle for resources and survival is fierce. Life is worthless. Bands of gangers raid villages, dangerous mutants lurk in the ruins ... Welcome to the Wasteland, welcome to Punkapocalyptic.

—description from the publisher

Name: Blame Space
Description:
Blame Space is a fast-paced card game of luck, skill and sheer bloody-mindedness. In space! For 2 to 6 spaced-out players. Playing time approx. 45 – 90 minutes.

The Story So Far... Our mission has failed, The captain has been murdered, Systems are sabotaged, A virus has been brought on board...

The ship’s computer is determined to find and punish the traitor who caused this mess. Maybe it's you! There's only one way you’re getting off this ship alive: Blame someone else!

On your turn, play Issue cards from your hand onto the Blame pile. You can play up to 3 cards or you may choose to play no cards.

Each card played must share at least one Duty icon with the card beneath it.
However, if you play a Betrayal or Infected card, you can play no other cards on the same turn (you play 1 card).

The number of cards you played determines which action you must take.

When someone is blamed, the accuser and accused crewmember go through the Issues in the Blame pile and count their respective Blame points. The one with the most points takes the Blame. The accuser takes it if the points are tied.

At the end of the game: count all your Blame points from the Issues in your hand. The more you have, the worse your chances of survival.

The game ends immediately when the last card is drawn (or turned over) from the Draw pile. The crewmember who does this must take the Blame!

Name: Siege of Tenochtitlan 1521 & The Noche Triste 1520
Description:
This game was published in Vae Victis magazine #139.

It's a bonus for CortÃ©s et la conquÃªte du Mexique 1519-1521 which was published in Vae Victis #137 and offer to play these battles separately or with the campaign. It allows you to resolve the siege on a special tactical map when it is held in ZS 22 of Tenochtitlan or to independently simulate the Noche Triste (June 26 to July 1, 1520) and the siege of Tenochtitlan (May 26 to August 13, 1521).

Name: Tight Cowboy
Description: There are some robbers, sergeants and villagers from everywhere crowd at the bar in a little desert town. At the bar, you should identify other's capacity agilely and choose one of these action to do with them like taking out your gun, robbing some coins or making your opponent drunk. The player who gain more coins in a muddle would be a winner.

Name: Half-Pint Heroes: Happy Hour
Description:
It‘s happy hour at Half-Pint Pub, and the rules are changing. Experience a totally new way to play this trick-taking game! During play, attach (removable) stickers to the cards to change their value or modify other game rules. The longer you play, the more new effects are added to the game. It's a riot!

Half-Pint Heroes: Happy Hour is the first ever legacy trick-taking game. Each player gets a sheet of stickers. Depending on their prediction, each player may place one sticker per round on one of their cards.

By putting more and more stickers on the cards, players not only change cards values but also some rules in the game. All stickers remain in effect until the end of the game, then they can be removed easily.

The expansion also adds material for two more players, so Half-Pint Heroes can now be played with up to nine players.

Name: Scream Aim Fire: WW2 Wargaming Rules
Description:
Scream Aim Fire is a set of miniatures wargame rules for the Second World War.

Before play, a deck is created with a card for each vehicle or squad of infantry. In each turn, cards are drawn, one at a time, to determine which unit attempts to activate next. A unit that fails to active has to take a shock and awe test to avoid being eliminated! A unit that does successfully activate, or one that fails but survives the shock and awe test, gets three dice to divide between movement, loading, and firing. Fire is resolved by a mixture of dice rolls and chit draws.

In the interests of a quick and simple game, differentiation between different unit types is minimal: all tanks are the same, for example.

Name: Go Oink!
Description:
Go Oink or moo, or cock-a-doodle-doo. You make the sound of the animal pictured on your card in order to ask other players if they have the animal you are requesting.

If the player has the animal you are requesting, they must give you all of those cards. Otherwise, that player says Go Oink and you take the top card from the draw pile. If you draw the card you asked for, take another turn. Otherwise, play passes to the left.  Whenever you have three matching animal cards, place them in a pile in front of you. These cards are safe from other players.

The game ends when any player gets rid of all card in their hands or when the draw pile runs out. The player with the most sets (3 of the same animal) wins

It's like Go Fish, but a little sillier and louder. If you enjoy acting like an animal, you'll go wild over this card game. The cards come in a big pig storage case.

Name: Superfight: 2017 Year in Review
Description:
Mini expansion sold at conventions. Contains 12 White and 6 Black cards that can be added to any Superfight game.

White:
Fidget Spinner
Mocking Spongebob
The Kids from Stranger Things
Kim Jong Un
Trio of Amazon Warriors
An Evil Clown That Can Turn Into Opponent's Greatest Fears
The Cast of the Emoji Movie
Schoolchildren Armed to Defend Themselves From Bears
United Airlines
Distracted Boyfriend
Pick A Hurricane
Salt Bae

Black:
Armed With A Magical Can of Pepsi That Solves Everyone's Problems
Riding an Undead Ice Dragon
Opponent's Character Was Forced to Resign and Replaced by (Draw a Random Character Card)
Staring at a Total Solar Eclipse
Armed With a Szechuan Sauce Fire Hose
Opponent's Attributes are Fake News

Name: Infinite Evil
Description:
Infinite Evil is a sci-fi RPG miniatures board game for 1-4 players in development by Intfury games studio.
Several mutually hostile groups are locked on a transport spaceship with a broken main engine. The game features 4 squads. Each squad has its own goal. The game ends by accomplishing this goal or by destroying all other players.
There are 9 characters in a squad. A player loses if all his characters die or another player completes his goal. Basically players move in turns, trying to take a profitable position and not to give another player to go to the key mission elements that he was unable to achieve his goal. By completing missions, a player acquires money, resources and new battle cards. A battle takes place if players are near, within one cell.
A player can accumulate 30 cards in the deck, but he can use only 10 in a battle. A battle consists of 1 round. All battle cards have a description of the action. Players count the number of points (written on the cards) at the end of the round. Who have more points - the winner. But you need to take into account the ability of the cards, if any. Card abilities are diverse: plus to protect, to attack, and so on. The winner gets money or a new card. The loser loses the character who participated in the battle.
Cards: 
Special cards has description of their action and no points. 
Special cards are very powerful. One card can cause damage to 3 cards or, for example, to revive your squad. 
Battle cards has description of their action and there are points on them. Battle cards places to battlefield board which divided in three rows (for each player).
The characters are divided into 3 groups. Each group placed in a row.
1st row - melee group.
2nd row - middle range group.
3rd row - long range group.
Each row corresponds to the icon: melee, medium range, long range. A card can be placed to the correct type of row only.
A melee character can only be placed in a melee row and attacks enemy's cards in a 1st row. Also melee group can add points for your group in another row.
Middle range character can be placed in a middle range row only. Middle range group can attack enemy's cards in 1st and 2nd rows.
Long range character can be placed in a long range row only and attacks enemy's cards in all three rows. Points are counted at the end of the battle.
Release of the game is scheduled for February 2019.

Name: Jujo
Description:
Jujo is a strategy/area control game for 2-5 players for ages 8+ that can be completed in 30-40 minutes. The object of the game is to keep your troops together while attacking opposing players. The player who obtains the most points through contiguous tiles wins. The game has a comic, marshal theme.

To start the game, each player shakes their respective game bags with the associated tiles, then randomly pulls out five tiles and places them on the side of the game board. These tiles will not be used in the game. The players can then place the remaining twenty tiles near the game board for use during the game.

The first player places any one of the twenty tiles in any of the squares, with the front side facing up. The next player follows, then the third and fourth players, who place tiles on the board until there is no space left. Players score points by having contiguous, numbered tiles of the same color. Two or more contiguous numbered tiles are called runs. Two or more numbered tiles must be touching, otherwise no points will be given. A player can have multiple runs.

There are several different ways to attack opposing players or to protect a player's troops. The use of offensive or defensive tactics makes the game interesting, and is central to the game's strategy.

The player who scores the most points at the end of the game wins. Points are tallied by adding up runs.

Name: Dwarves with Swords
Description:
Dwarves with Swords is a tabletop war game that deals with the daily struggles of dwarven clans: Who has the beer? Who is the better fighter? AND WHERE DID ALL THE HAMMERS GO?!?.  The game has two primary objectives.  Brawl and fight to the death or control areas for victory points.

There are two primary game mechanisms in Dwarves with Swords.  The first is Group Building, where the player picks from four different dwarf classes and builds groups of nine to use in combat. Each of these different classes has things they are good at and things they are weak at, so it's important to build the groups based on the map objectives and personal play style.

The second is the actual combat, which is determined by rolling dice according to both the actions that are chosen for the groups and the relevant stat value (Armor, Dexterity, Strength, Knowledge, and Wisdom). The comparison of the attacking roll and the defending roll is done in a way that is unique to Dwarves with Swords, and makes use of all of the different die sizes that we love.

Another major component of the combat is Drunkenness. Every point of Drunkenness that the group has increases its combat stats while decreasing its Speed - but if the group reaches a Drunkenness level equal or greater than its Memory, the group Blacks Out and is removed from the board. All good dwarves know how to hold their booze, so being eliminated from the game this way is incredibly embarrassing!

—description from the designer

Name: Champions of Midgard: Bjorn Hammerblow the Fantastic promo
Description:
A promo originally available at Geekway to the West 2018

A new Champions of Midgard viking leader board.

Ability:
Whenever you kill a troll gain 1 resource of your choice.

Leader Power: "Tonight We Dine In Valhalla"
Discard a completed enemy card and collect 3 Food from the supply. (If you have no enemy cards, gain 1 Food instead.)

Name: Executive Order
Description:
You're a fresh Commander-In-Chief spending your first day in The Oval Office. There are a million promises you need to keep that you made on the campaign trail, but there's one that echoes through those who've supported you: build the wall. The only problem is there are those who want to do it before you and take all your glory. But you can't let that happen, you're the greatest! Nobody is better than you.
 Executive Order is a game of quickness and trolling as you fight to complete your wall before your competitors. But will you go straight for the glory and complete your wall? Or will you instead make it as difficult as possible for your competitors to complete theirs?

Use cards to create strategic moves and shuffle things around. Don’t like your current hand? Play “Alternative Facts” and draw a new one. Somebody put down a Wall card before you? Play “Congress” to have it taken away.

Ideal for 2-7  players 13 and over. Gameplay averages 30 minutes or more.

In Executive Order, the goal for players is to be the first to have three active Wall cards in front of them on the table. Players take turns by playing a card from their hand, resolving its action, and then drawing back up to their hand size. Some cards that can be played include "Wall" cards, "Budget Cuts" (reduces a players hand size by one card), "Congress" (removes an active wall card from in front of a player), "Deport"  (cancels a players card and returns it to their hand), or "Umm, No!" (cancels a players turn). Players can even debate on the table by creating a stack of "Deports" and "Ummm, Nos" until someone claims victory!

Players can also add  new rules by playing the "Executive Order" card. But be careful, a "Court Ruling" card can put your rule to a vote to see if it remains or a player can play "AltTwit@ExeOrder" to exempt themselves from the rule!

Name: Pacific 1942 Islands
Description:
In front of you lies the Pacific Ocean and your goal is to gain twelve victory points by conquering the islands and sinking enemy ships.

Pacific 1942 Islands is the version of the core game Pacific 1942 Admiral created in 2018.

New scenario. The new goal of the game.

The main changes:

Unlimited range of aircraft, the speed of the ships does not depend on their strength.
Aircraft ships begin the game off the harbour. 
Japanese Admiral starts the game with a massive strike on Pearl Harbor.
No new ships can be repaired or built during the game.

—description from the publisher

Name: Serial Killer
Description:
Serial Killer is a real-time party game that uses signaling, bluffing, and deduction.

The game simulates the situation where most of the players are assigned as innocent civilians in a city with an undercover killer and police.

The objective of the police is to find the killer before the killer eliminates all of the civilians.

The killer's intention is to eliminate innocent civilians by means of a secret signal. The killer has less than five minutes to secretly signal their murder target without revealing themselves to the police. If the killer's murder attempt is successful, they will need to wait for at least 10 seconds before making another attempt. In the meantime, the killer is also trying to confuse the police into capturing the wrong player.

Civilian roles make the game more complex and interesting. The Journalist, for example, is an innocent civilian with the ability to expose other player's characters.

The game includes 30 characters with 10 unique roles. Each roles has a different agenda. Various characters can help the police or the killer or even themselves to win the game.

This game is easy to play, and can be played anywhere--in a small circle of friends or with family or as a team-building exercise.

Name: Evil Overlord
Description:
You are an Evil Mastermind, just waiting for your time at the top!

Of course, you're not alone in that, and you'll have to defeat the others if you want to rule the world as the Evil Overlord!

Unfortunately, your rag-tag army won't fight together, so you'll have to go to the "Evil Minion Market" and trade away the minions you don't want!

Evil Overlord is a Deck Building game condensed into 5-10 minutes

It is for 3-10 players of ages 6+

The cards represent the troops in your army

You can only play one army type, so you trade away the cards you don't want to the other players!

Everyone gets to trade, not just the loud people!

Doesn't require a moderator or phone app!

—description from the designer

Name: Yesterday's War: The Salvage
Description:
Yesterday's War: The Salvage is a small box worker placement game set in a sci-fi post-apocalypse.

It’s been fifty years since the War ended, and two hundred and thirty since the War began. The city of Elysium stands bright and shining in a sea of ashes and rubble. It's the largest city on Earth and the only place where air can be safely breathed.

Everything in Elysium is built from recycled parts from the War. You and up to three other players are salvage workers who wander the wasteland in search of old war machines that can be scrapped for parts. Each salvage worker has four mechs to gather resources and a special ability that gives them an advantage in the game. Salvage workers will fulfill contracts, achieve objectives, earn rewards, and fight raiders - all in the pursuit of sweet, sweet victory points.

—description from the publisher

Name: Farmer Olaf
Description:
After the fall of the greatest dwarven city, Arar, many years ago, almost all dwarves left the Valley of Three Passes. Now, Olaf's farm — the last one in the valley — has been struck by an earthquake. Dwarf Olaf sends for you, his grandchildren, to help him rebuild his farm and find his lost animals. He promises to reveal the biggest secret of the fallen city to the one who helps him the most.

Farmer Olaf is the first "no.table" family tabletop game (or so the publisher seems to think), which means it can be played comfortably on a big or small table — or on no table at all. The unique box design allows discarding and storing cards while holding it in one hand or being attached to a belt. Other advantages include starting or stopping game in seconds, quick save/quick load game ability, burst card dealing, quick independent release, and rules storage that doubles as a displayable cheat sheet. The maximum number of players is determined by game boxes used (with  four additional players for each game box).

In Farmer Olaf, players perform four farming activities to gather green cards with points. The player with the most points at the end of the game wins. Farming activities include sowing and harvesting a field, milking a yak, making wool from alpaca, and making ham from a boar. Each player receives five cards at the start of the game and one card on each subsequent turn. Players try to collect appropriate cards for farming actions. For the most part, there is a shortage of buildings and animals needed for production. This means that in order to increase their chances of winning, a player needs to engage in trade with others. There are no limits of how to structure trades: from traditional 1-1 card exchange to more exotic deals like leasing or deferred payment. The game is carefully balanced as, for example, the best cards are steam machines that can be used only to sow and harvest a field. However, to do that one needs a fertilizer that can be obtained only by cleaning a boar pen or cowshed.

Simple rules and design (no text and no numbers on cards) allow children aged 5+ to participate in the game when playing with adults. The most demanding part is being a game master and managing cards in the box, thus the overall 10+ age rating.

Name: Cut the Rope: Magic
Description:
OM NOM!

Mobile devices are unable to constrain Cut the Rope in digital form. The game managed to escape to the table — MAGIC!

Little green monster Om Nom loves candy. But it is so hard to get it! Help him get the sweets by playing chains of cards. Don’t forget to use the scissors card at the right time. Be careful – your opponents want to become the best friend of Om Nom too! To win, you will have to play smart and watch other players carefully.

In the beginning of the game, each player gets a pile of numbered cards. The goal of each player is to get rid of all the cards from their pile. A top card from a player’s pile can be played to any one of three available “levels”. However, you can only play cards to form chains in “levels”.

Cards in chains have to go in ascending or descending order and no number can be skipped. Players also have a hand of cards. Cards from the hand can be used to form “supplies”. Cards from “supplies” can be played to “levels” as well.

Cut the Rope: Magic is a bright successor of Cut the Rope: The Card Game set in a magic world of the broadly known mobile app expansion.

Name: The Grid: AI Awakens
Description:
With no two games ever the same, The Grid is a dynamic card-driven game for 2 to 4 players set around one of the most intriguing, disruptive and unnerving breakthroughs of the 21st century: self-aware Artificial Intelligence.

As a world-leading scientist, you race your fellow researchers to take control of the Grid: a set of technological pillars that once discovered, will lead to the first true AI.

Yet, you do not only compete with others. In an unusual twist, you also face off against a fledgling, rapidly-evolving AI who also seeks to command the Grid - the very parts that make up its being.

To take on The Grid, you’ll research 12 critical technologies like robotics and cognitive science, protect them from AI attack with firewalls, manipulate The Grid to claim a strategic advantage, or reclaim a pillar overrun by the awakening artificial force.

In your mission to harness AI, you’ll use Development cards to give you research-enabling brain power or influence. But your fate is not entirely in your hands; progress will continually be shaped by Contingencies that reveal unexpected traits within yourself, deliver useful power-ups to accelerate research or introduce game-changing events - such as AI Attack - that can instantly change the balance of power.

The path to AI supremacy is clear. Collect tech and victory tokens as you research technology pillars, or overtake them from opposing forces. Complete critical secret missions that strengthen your claim of AI control. Once the Grid is fully developed, the scientist with the most points has won, unlocking the infinite potential of AI for all of humanity.

But be careful not to focus too much on the scientific rivalry. The juvenile AI also seeks control of The Grid. When the time comes, put aside differences and work together to repel it… or risk giving this artificial force the power to escape into the world and confront mankind with an uncertain future.

When you set out to master The Grid, you do so with numerous decks of exquisite cards and tokens that have been carefully crafted to immerse you in a futuristic frontier of self-aware intelligence.

Fight to harness the phenomenal power of The Grid. But be sure to control it… or it will control you.

Name: Getting Started With Warhammer 40,000
Description:
Getting Started With Warhammer 40,000 contains the basic ruleset for playing games of Warhammer 40,000, with each phase broken down into simple explanations. There’s even a mission included to get everyone playing right away.

Everything you need to get started in the galaxy of Warhammer 40,000, this magazine is the for the absolute beginner who’d like to dip their toes in the hobby of collecting, building, painting and playing with Citadel miniatures. It explains in easy to follow terms how to get started, and even comes with a free push-fit Primaris Space Marine Intercessor miniature.

Contained in the 104-page magazine:


     A history of the Warhammer 40,000 setting – the story so far, the state of the galaxy and the dramatic history that led to it;
     A guide to the armies you can collect and play with in Warhammer 40,000, showing you their motivations and introducing their histories;
     Guidance on collecting Citadel miniatures – while you can simply pick up any that catch your eye, for many the hobby is about specific armies or types of miniature. This guide includes three example collections for inspiration, with a further showcase of beautifully-painted miniatures from a variety of armies;
     A detailed Battle Report – watch as the heroic Ultramarines take on the vile Death Guard in a tense fight to the end;
     A guide to some of the most famous war zones of Warhammer 40,000, and the epic battles that took place there;
     An introduction to painting Citadel miniatures using the Citadel Paint System, with a guide to paints, brushes and step-by-step instructions showing how to paint a variety of miniatures – including your free Intercessor!

Name: Grantara: The Breath of Evil
Description:
A board game where 1-2 players can play for the master of evil, while the other 1-2 players will resist them, playing for the forces of good, exploring different locations and picking the loot from the defeated forces of evil.

The game is designed for 2-4 players, where players will need to make tactical and strategic decisions to achieve their goals. Each player will be able to choose whom he will play for monsters or squad.

In this game, the player has to wisely approach the selection of the setup squad, and the player managing the monster must predict the actions of the enemy in which the quantitative advantage.

Playing for the squad player can choose one of the two factions (1st version) and hire a team for their wanderings through a dangerous and at the same time wonderful world of the game.

On his turn, the player of the squad(s) can explore the dungeon, engaging in battle with monsters, rotten squads of the evil master, and also collect treasures for winning in battle.

The master of evil on his turn can control monsters, send rotten squads, strengthen his power and in every possible way prevent the squads from surviving in the dungeon.

The game has unique mechanics and many nuances and features that turn each battle into challenges for each side.

The aim of the evil master is to collect a certain number of points, which is determined by the length of the adventure, after reaching the targets the opponents will be considered defeated.

The objective of the squad(s) is to pass the dungeon the length of which they choose at the beginning of the adventure, and also fulfill certain conditions on the last location.

The journey is considered complete when one of the parties fulfills its victory conditions.

Name: Golden Islands
Description:
"Golden Islands" - a gambling and fun game with easy rules for 2-4 players, age 8+, in which you take on the role of the captain of the ship. You will plow the ocean, exploring the islands and collecting gold coins. Of course, it will not do without battles with other captains! Despite the seeming simplicity, the game has many strategies and options for progress towards victory!

The goal of the game is collecting gold coins. To win, you need to collect more coins than other players.

On your turn you will travel between islands (you choose your way), fight with other players and, using dice, play different events (good or bad).

Turn sequence:

Players turn consists of three phases: moving, battle and event.

- Moving:
        Move your pawn to any neighboring island (including any starting position). You can move only vertically or horizontally (orthogonally). If another player is already on the island, go to the battle phase. If the coin is on the island, pick it up and put it in front of you, then go to the event phase. If the island has neither a coin nor another player - go to the event phase.

- Battle:
        If you moved to an island on which another player is already located, it means that you attacked him. Proceed to battle. Each player has three health markers that represent the state of your ship. The battle consists of a series of rounds - attacks. Both players roll one die each. The player, who has less value, gets damaged and turns over one of his health markers. If both players have the same values, the dice are thrown. Attack is repeated until one of the players turns his last, third, health marker - this player lost in this fight. After the end of the battle, the winner takes half of the coins from the loser (rounding up), and the loser returns to his starting position. Players reverse their health markers (repairs the ship). If the losing player does not have a single coin, the winner does not receive anything. This ends your turn.

- Event:
        The event is played if you moved to an island on which there is no other player. Throw three dice and play the event which corresponds to the rolled dice value. This ends your turn.

Name: The Flower Essence Game
Description:
Designed by award-winning Napoleonic wargame designer Kevin Zucker, this flower game is used for learning the names and properties of flower essences.

Seven flower cards are dealt to each player, dealing the cards one at a time, picture side up, so that all the cards can be seen at the same time. Three symptom (green) cards are laid out in the center of the playing area face-up. The players agree on a famous real or fictional person who fits the "patient profile".

Players scan over the flower cards and turn over 1, 2, or 3 cards that their eyes land on first. Each player turns over his or her own cards. Read the separate cards and pick one that relates to the symptom or symptoms, explaining to the other players how this addresses the symptom. Each player in turn plays one flower card that best addresses the symptom or symptoms, explaining how this applies. Players scan over the remaining cards in front of them and pick those they wish to turn over. Repeat these steps until all the cards that each player wants to introduce have been played.

Discuss which of the flower essence cards introduced into play by the players best fit the symptoms. Refer to the Flower Essence Repertory as needed. There may be more than one right answer. The goal is to agree on up to 5 essences for the perfect blend to fit the patient's symptoms.

Items required

• One deck of Affirm a Flower affirmation cards (published by FES)

• One deck of Green Apple cards from the game Apples to Apples®

...

Example of play:  If Marilyn Monroe is considered to be the "patient", the following might happen when the flower cards are examined. The first player played "Pretty Face" which says "I accept all parts of my self. Light shines through darkness and pain. My whole self is my beautiful self. I am this Shining Star." The second player played "Dogwood" which says "My body is healed by flowing grace. I release what has become hardened. This gentle purity fills body and soul. I feel the blessing of grace-filled life." It was determined that either flower card would help address the life challenges of Marilyn Monroe, and both players were considered to have right answers.

There are also solitaire and advanced versions of this game.
Families: Admin: Outside the Scope of BGG

Name: Gardens of Enceladus
Description:
Our beloved Martians from Gardens of Mars and Gardens of Io have travelled to Saturn’s moon Enceladus to harvest the flowers they planted last year.

Help your little Martian gardener harvest the flowers making sure he collects enough of each type.

RULES SUMMARY (please refer to the official rulebook for details)

MATERIAL

- A board representing both a garden on icy Enceladus (10×10 squares), and 10 special actions.
- 95 flowers in 5 different colours (19 each).
- A carrying case.
- 6 black Martians in 3 types (2 each).
- 4 white Martians in 2 types (2 each).
- 5 peaks (white pyramids).
- 9 black counters.
- 1 ‘silver’ counter (the wildflower).

GAMEPLAY

Players take turns moving their martians orthogonally, landing on a space with a flower and taking it. Then taking an adjacent flower. Finally taking all isolated flowers from the board (soliflowers; those that don't have orthogonally adjancent flowers).

Optionally, at the beginning of the turn, the players can execute special actions by 'purchasing' them with 3 flowers of the same colour. Each action can only be executed once during the game:

- Randomly pick 3 flowers from the game case (don’t look), if there are at least 3, and add them to your reserve1.

- Jump orthogonally (not diagonally) over a peak to a space not occupied by a martian. If there is a flower on it, add it to your reserve. Don’t take an adjacent flower!

- Move diagonally to a space not occupied by a martian (you cannot jump over peaks). If there is a flower on it, add it to your reserve. Don’t take an adjacent flower!

- Pick any flower from the board and add it to your reserve.

- Swap the positions of your martian and any one peak or planted flower.

- Swap the positions of any one peak and any one planted flower.

- Swap the positions of any 2 planted flowers.

- Move any one planted flower to any empty space of the garden.

- Move any peak to any empty space of the garden.

- Pick the wildflower and add it to your reserve. Do not place a black counter on the circle; when this unique wildflower is gone, this special action is unavailable.

GAME END AND SCORING

If a player can't move her martian to a space occupied by a flower the game ends.

To get your score, count the number of flowers of the colour you have the least (consider the 6 colours, even if you don’t have flowers of some of them!). The wildflower acts as a wildcard; it can be used as any colour but you have to declare which one before scoring.

The player with the highest score wins. Ties are broken by the second colour you have the least and so on. If the tie persists play again.

-description from designer

Name: CastQuest
Description:
CastQuest is a description based, strategic party game with a touch of magic.

The aim of the game is to describe random combinations of creatures, their weapons, and the armour they wear without using the words written on the cards. If this is done correctly, you are awarded with cards from a deck of 'Fate Cards' that contain spells to help yourself progress, curses to make it harder for your opponents, and separate elements to a quest... you need these in order to win.

The quest elements are made up of 'WHO', 'WHAT', and 'WHERE' - once you've collected a sequence, and successfully described/guessed enough combinations of Creature, Weapon, and Armour - you enter into the victory round.

VICTORY ROUND:
Embark upon a quickfire guessing round against a chosen opponent in order to revisit the previous creature, weapon and armour cards from the game. A third player describes this time, but can only use one word to do so - so make sure you're paying attention to everyone's description rounds throughout the game, as it may come in handy!

If you are the one attempting victory and get more correct quickfire guesses than your defending opponent, you have successfully Cast your Quest, and won the game!

—description from the publisher

Name: Repulse
Description:
Repulse is a strategic card game consisting of 110 cards in 3 categories.

Is a good defense perhaps better than an attack? Can it be that you set up the tactic that leads to the goal? Are you ready?

Regardless of the game variant, it’s about being the first to defeat another army, so there are no more cards in front of an opponent. Always keep in mind that a wrong move may allow another player to win the game.

On your turn: Pick up two cards from the middle of the pile (or your own - depending on the game variant). You can attack with the face-up cards you face. You can play some action cards in your hand at any time (during an attack or while another player's turn takes place), others only when it's your turn. Once you've completed your attacks, you can reveal up to two face-down cards (or just one or none at all) and put them forward and replace them with hand cards. A maximum of 3 cards may be revealed and two cards face down. Think good of your strategy, because if you make too many attacks, you may not be able to defend yourself.

If an attack is made and it succeeds by higher value, both cards are placed on the open stack in the middle. If the attacker's army card value is lower than the defending card, the attack failed and the attack card is placed on the open stack in the middle.

—description from the designer

Name: 7th Voyage: The Witching Hour
Description:
Inspired by the folklore and tales of gothic horror, you take command of the heroes or villians of legend! The Witching Hour is written entirely by Glenn Allan, and presented by Crooked Dice.

Send the Headless Horseman back to the depths of hell or command the gruesome witch-hunts from the dark days of history with this new 7th Voyage gothic horror supplement. You will need a copy of the 7th Voyage rules to use this product.

The Witching Hour adds new stars, co-stars and extras profiles, as well as new scenarios, Gifts of the Gods and Events.
Families: Series: action engine (Crooked Dice Game Design Studio)

Name: Disloyal Royals
Description:
Disloyal Royals is a two player card game that uses only standard playing cards and dice. At the beginning of the game, each player is dealt a jack, queen, and king. This is your royal family. The royal family wants to collect riches (diamonds) and bury them (face down) for safe keeping.
